Potassium ion in a $250.0( \pm 0.1) \mathrm{mL}$ water sample was precipitated with sodium tetraphenylborate:
$\mathrm{K}^{+}+\left(\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{5}\right)_{4} \mathrm{~B}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{KB}\left(\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{5}\right)_{4}(s)$
The precipitate was filtered, washed, dissolved in an organic solvent, and treated with excess $\mathrm{Hg}(\text { EDTA })^{2-}$ :
$\begin{aligned}4 \mathrm{HgY}^{2-}+\left(\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{5}\right)_{4}\mathrm{~B}^{-}+ & 4 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \rightarrow \\& \mathrm{H}_{3} \mathrm{BO}_{3}+4 \mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{5} \mathrm{Hg}^{+}+4 \mathrm{HY}^{3-}+\mathrm{OH}^{-}\end{aligned}$
The liberated EDTA was titrated with $28.73( \pm 0.03) \mathrm{mL}$ of 0.0437 $( \pm 0.0001) \mathrm{M} \mathrm{Zn}^{2+}$. Find $\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right]$(and its absolute uncertainty) in the original sample.【analysis】Calculate the content of potassium based on relevant chemical reaction knowledge
【answer】Calculate through the first and second chemical reactions

For every mole of $\mathrm{K}^{+}$entering the first reaction, 4 moles of EDTA are produced in the second reaction.
Moles of EDTA $=$ moles of $\mathrm{Zn}^{2+}$ used in titration
$\begin{aligned}{\left[\mathrm{K}^{+}\right] } & =\frac{\frac{1}{4}\left(\text { moles of } \mathrm{Zn}^{2+}\right)}{\text { volume of original sample }} \\
& =\frac{\frac{1}{4}[28.73( \pm 0.03)][0.0437( \pm 0.0001)]}{250.0( \pm 0.1)} \\
& =\frac{\left[\frac{1}{4}( \pm 0 \%)\right][28.73( \pm 0.104 \%)][0.0437( \pm 0.229 \%)]}{250.0( \pm 0.0400 \%)} \\
& =1.256( \pm 0.255 \%) \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{M}=1.256( \pm 0.003) \mathrm{mM}\end{aligned}$
【In summary，$[\mathrm{K}^+]=1.256 (\pm0.003) mM$】

millimoles EDTA used: $(25.00 \mathrm{~mL})(0.05083 \mathrm{M})=1.2708$

0.8985

Suppose that $0.0100 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$ is titrated with $0.00500 \mathrm{M}$ EDTA at $\mathrm{pH} 7.00$.
(a) What is the concentration of free $\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$ at the equivalence point?
(b) What is the quotient $\left[\mathrm{H}_{3} \mathrm{Y}^{-}\right] /\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{Y}^{2-}\right]$ in the solution when the titration is just $63.7 \%$ of the way to the equivalence point?【analysis】Calculate concentration and quotient based on known values and related formulas
【answer】(a)Substitute numerical values into the formula 

One volume of $\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$ requires two volumes of EDTA to reach the equivalence point. The formal concentration of $\mathrm{MnY}^{2-}$ at the equivalence point is $\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)(0.0100 \mathrm{M})=0.00333 \mathrm{M}$.
$\begin{gathered}
\mathrm{Mn}_{x}^{2+}+\underset{x}{\mathrm{EDTA}} \rightleftharpoons \underset{0.00333-x}{\mathrm{MnY}^{2-}} \\
\frac{0.00333-x}{x^{2}}=\alpha_{\mathrm{Y}^{4}-K_{\mathrm{f}}}=\left(3.8 \times 10^{-4}\right) 10^{13.89}=2.9 \times 10^{10} \\
\Rightarrow x=\left[\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}\right]=3.4 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{M}
\end{gathered}$
(b)Based on the constant pH and related formula conversion, the results are obtained 

$\mathrm{pH}$ is constant, so the quotient $\left[\mathrm{H}_{3} \mathrm{Y}^{-}\right] /\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{Y}^{2-}\right]$ is constant throughout the entire titration.
$\frac{\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{Y}^{2-}\right]\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{H}_{3} \mathrm{Y}^{-}\right]}=K_{4} \Rightarrow \frac{\left[\mathrm{H}_{3} \mathrm{Y}^{-}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{Y}^{2-}\right]}=\frac{\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]}{K_{4}}=\frac{10^{-7.00}}{10^{-2.69}}=4.9 \times 10^{-5}$
【In summary，$\frac{\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{Y}^{2-}\right]\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{H}_{3} \mathrm{Y}^{-}\right]}=4.9 \times 10^{-5}$】

Suppose that $0.0100 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$ is titrated with $0.00500 \mathrm{M}$ EDTA at $\mathrm{pH} 7.00$.
(a) What is the concentration of free $\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$ at the equivalence point?
(b) What is the quotient $\left[\mathrm{H}_{3} \mathrm{Y}^{-}\right] /\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{Y}^{2-}\right]$ in the solution when the titration is just $63.7 \%$ of the way to the equivalence point?(a) The titration of $0.0100 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$ with $0.00500 \mathrm{M}$ EDTA at $\mathrm{pH} 7.00$ is an acid-base滴定，利用EDTA与$\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$形成可溶的配合物。滴定终点时，$\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$的浓度即为其在溶液中的溶解度。

首先，求出$\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$的摩尔质量：
$$\mathrm{M}(\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}) = \frac{\mathrm{0.0100 \mathrm{M}}}{2} = 0.00500 \mathrm{M}$$

在pH 7.00的溶液中，$\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$的溶解度积为：
$$K_s(\mathrm{Mn}^{2+},\mathrm{H_2O}) = \left[\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}\right] \left[\mathrm{H_3} \mathrm{O}^2\right] = \left(\frac{\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}}{2}\right) \left[\mathrm{H_3} \mathrm{O}^2\right]$$

代入已知数据，得到：
$$K_s(\mathrm{Mn}^{2+},\mathrm{H_2O}) = \left(\frac{0.00500 \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}}{2}\right) \left[\mathrm{H_3} \mathrm{O}^2\right] = \frac{K_w}{4} = \frac{10^{-14}}{4} = 2.5 \times 10^{-15}$$

因为$\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$和$\mathrm{H_3} \mathrm{O}^2$的浓度相等，所以：
$$\left[\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}\right] = \sqrt{\frac{K_s(\mathrm{Mn}^{2+},\mathrm{H_2O})}{K_w}} = \sqrt{\frac{2.5 \times 10^{-15}}{10^{-14}}} = 2.5 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{M}$$

所以，在pH 7.00的溶液中，$\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$的浓度为$2.5 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{M}$。

(b) 在滴定过程中，$\mathrm{H_3} \mathrm{Y}^{-}$和$\mathrm{H_2} \mathrm{Y}^{2-}$的浓度分别为：
$$\left[\mathrm{H_3} \mathrm{Y}^{-}\right] = \frac{\mathrm{0.0100 \mathrm{M}}}{2} - 0.00500 \mathrm{M} = 0.00500 \mathrm{M}$$
$$\left[\mathrm{H_2} \mathrm{Y}^{2-}\right] = \frac{\mathrm{0.0100 \mathrm{M}}}{2} - 0.00500 \mathrm{M} = 0.00500 \mathrm{M}$$

当滴加到$63.7\%$的终点时，$\mathrm{H_3} \mathrm{Y}^{-}$和$\mathrm{H_2} \mathrm{Y}^{2-}$的浓度均为：
$$\left[\mathrm{H_3} \mathrm{Y}^{-}\right] = \left[\mathrm{H_2} \mathrm{Y}^{2-}\right] = \frac{\mathrm{0.0100 \mathrm{M}}}{2} \times \left(1 - \sqrt{1 - \left(\frac{0.637}{100}\right)^2}\right) = 0.00667 \mathrm{M}$$

所以，$\left[\mathrm{H_3} \mathrm{Y}^{-}\right] / \left[\mathrm{H_2} \mathrm{Y}^{2-}\right] = \frac{0.00667 \mathrm{M}}{0.00500 \mathrm{M}} = 1.334$。

Suppose that $0.0100 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$ is titrated with $0.00500 \mathrm{M}$ EDTA at $\mathrm{pH} 7.00$.
(a) What is the concentration of free $\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$ at the equivalence point?
(b) What is the quotient $\left[\mathrm{H}_{3} \mathrm{Y}^{-}\right] /\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{Y}^{2-}\right]$ in the solution when the titration is just $63.7 \%$ of the way to the equivalence point?(a) The titration of $0.0100 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$ with $0.00500 \mathrm{M}$ EDTA at $\mathrm{pH} 7.00$ is an acid-base滴定。在滴定终点时，溶液中的$\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$离子的浓度等于$\mathrm{EDTA}$的摩尔浓度，即$0.00500 \mathrm{M}$。

(b) 在滴定终点时，$\mathrm{Mn}^{2+}$离子和$\mathrm{Y}^{2-}$离子的浓度比为2:1。因此，$\left[\mathrm{H}_{3} \mathrm{Y}^{-}\right] /\left[\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{Y}^{2-}\right]=2/1$。

If$5.585 \mathrm{~g} $ of $\mathrm{ Fe}^{3+}$ were reduced in Reaction 13-1, how many coulombs of charge must have been transferred from $\mathrm{V}^{2+}$ to $\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$?【analysis】This problem mainly examines the charge balance knowledge in electrochemical reactions
【answer】This problem can be solved using the charge balance method

First, we find that $5.585 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$ equal $0.1000 \mathrm{~mol}$ of $\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$ . Because each $\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$ ion requires one electron in Reaction 13-1, $0.1000 \mathrm{~mol}$ of electrons must have been transferred. Using the Faraday constant, we find that $0.1000 \mathrm{~mol}$ of electrons corresponds to

$q=n F=\left(0.1000 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{e}^{-}\right)\left(9.649 \times 10^{4} \frac{\mathrm{C}}{\mathrm{mol} \mathrm{e}^{-}}\right)=9.649 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{C}$
【In summary，$q=9.649 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{C}$.】

If$5.585 \mathrm{~g} $ of $\mathrm{ Fe}^{3+}$ were reduced in Reaction 13-1, how many coulombs of charge must have been transferred from $\mathrm{V}^{2+}$ to $\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$?To determine the number of coulombs of charge that must have been transferred from $\mathrm{V}^{2+}$ to $\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$ in reaction 13-1, we first need to写出 the balanced chemical equation for the reaction:

$$\rm{Fe^{3+} + 3e^{-} -> Fe^{2+}}$$

This reaction is an oxidation-reduction reaction, where the $\rm{Fe}^{3+}$ ion is reduced to $\rm{Fe}^{2+}$ and gains 3 electrons. The number of electrons that are transferred in this reaction is 3.

Next, we need to determine the amount of $\rm{Fe}^{3+}$ that was reduced in the reaction. If $\rm{5.585 g}$ of $\rm{Fe}^{3+}$ were reduced in the reaction, we can calculate the amount of $\rm{Fe}^{3+}$ that was reduced by dividing the mass of $\rm{Fe}^{3+}}$ by the摩尔质量 of the Fe$^{3+}$ ion:

$$\rm{n_{Fe}^{3+}} = \frac{\rm{5.585 g}}{\rm{55.845 g/mol}} = 0.1000\ \rm{mol}$$

Now, we can use the balanced chemical equation to calculate the number of electrons that must have been transferred from $\rm{V}^{2+}$ to $\rm{Fe}^{3+}$:

$$\rm{n_{Fe}^{3+}} \times 3 = n_{V}^{2+} \times 2$$

Solving for $n_{V}^{2+}$, we get:

$$\rm{n_{V}^{2+}} = \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{\rm{5.585 g}}{\rm{55.845 g/mol}} = 0.0000\ \rm{mol}$$

This means that 0.0000 mol of $\rm{V}^{2+}$ was氧化成了 $\rm{Fe}^{3+}$，也就是说， 0.0000 mol of charge was transferred from $\rm{V}^{2+}$ to $\rm{Fe}^{3+}.$

Since one coulomb is equal to the charge of one proton, we can calculate the number of coulombs of charge that were transferred by multiplying the number of electrons by the number of protons in the ion:

$$\rm{Q = n_{Fe}^{3+}} \times N_{A} = 0.1000\ \rm{mol} \times 6.022 \times 10^{23} \ \rm{C/mol} = 6.022 \times 10^{21} \ \rm{C}$$

Therefore, if 5.585 g of $\rm{Fe}^{3+}$ were reduced in reaction 13-1, 6.022 x 10^21 coulombs of charge must have been transferred from $\rm{V}^{2+}$ to $\rm{Fe}^{3+}.$

If$5.585 \mathrm{~g} $ of $\mathrm{ Fe}^{3+}$ were reduced in Reaction 13-1, how many coulombs of charge must have been transferred from $\mathrm{V}^{2+}$ to $\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$?To determine the number of coulombs of charge that must have been transferred from $\mathrm{V}^{2+}$ to $\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$ in reaction 13-1, we need to know the电荷数（或称电荷）守恒定律。

根据电荷守恒定律，电荷数在反应前后保持不变。因此，我们可以通过计算反应前后电荷数的变化来确定答案。

首先，我们需要确定反应物和生成物的电荷数。给定的反应式是13-1，这意味着反应中涉及13个原子，其中12个是$\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$离子，1个是$\mathrm{V}^{2+}$离子。

反应前，$\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$离子的电荷数为3+，$\mathrm{V}^{2+}$离子的电荷数为2+。

反应后，$\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$离子的电荷数仍为3+，而$\mathrm{V}^{2+}$离子的电荷数变为3-。

根据电荷守恒定律，反应前后电荷数的变化应该相等。因此，我们可以计算反应前后电荷数的变化：

反应前：13 \* 3+ + 1 \* 2+ = 42 + 2 = 44

反应后：13 \* 3+ + 1 \* 3- = 42 + 3 = 45

可见，反应后电荷数增加了1。根据电荷守恒定律，这个增加的电荷数必须来自于反应物$\mathrm{V}^{2+}$。

现在我们需要计算$\mathrm{V}^{2+}$离子转移给$\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$离子的电荷数。我们可以通过计算反应物和生成物中每种离子的电荷数差来确定这个数值。

反应前，$\mathrm{V}^{2+}$离子的电荷数为2+，$\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$离子的电荷数为3+。

反应后，$\mathrm{V}^{2+}$离子的电荷数为2+，而$\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$离子的电荷数为3+。

因此，$\mathrm{V}^{2+}$离子转移给$\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$离子的电荷数为：

1 \* (3+ - 2+) = 1 \* 1 = 1

根据电荷守恒定律，这个数值等于反应前后电荷数的变化减去反应前电荷数和反应后电荷数之差。因此，我们可以得出答案：

1 coulombs（或称库伦）

How much work can be done if $2.4 \mathrm{mmol}$ of electrons fall through a potential difference of $0.27 \mathrm{~V}$ ?【analysis】This problem mainly examines the relationship between electric charge and potential difference, and the calculation of work through potential difference
【answer】To use Equation 13-3, we must convert moles of electrons into coulombs of charge.The relation is

$q=n F=\left(2.4 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~mol}\right)\left(9.649 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{mol}\right)=2.3 \times 10^{2} \mathrm{C}$
The work that could be done is
$\text { Work }=E \cdot q=(0.27 \mathrm{~V})\left(2.3 \times 10^{2} \mathrm{C}\right)=62 \mathrm{~J}$
【In summary，$\text { Work }=62 \mathrm{~J}$.】

How much work can be done if $2.4 \mathrm{mmol}$ of electrons fall through a potential difference of $0.27 \mathrm{~V}$ ?The amount of work that can be done by moving $2.4 \mathrm{mmol}$ of electrons through a potential difference of $0.27 \mathrm{~V}$ depends on the specific reaction and the energy barrier that the electrons must跨越.

In general, work can be defined as the amount of energy that is required to move a unit of charge through a potential difference of $V$. For example, if a cell is at a potential of $0\ \mathrm{V}$, adding $2.4 \mathrm{mmol}$ of electrons through a potential difference of $0.27 \mathrm{~V}$ would require the cell to invest $2.4 \mathrm{mmol} \times 0.27 \mathrm{J/e} = 0.6 \mathrm{J}$ in order to allow the electrons to跨过 the potential barrier.

However, this is just a rough estimate and does not take into account the specific reaction and the energy barrier that the electrons must跨越.

How much work can be done if $2.4 \mathrm{mmol}$ of electrons fall through a potential difference of $0.27 \mathrm{~V}$ ?The amount of work done by the electrons can be calculated using the formula for work done on a unit charge of an ion:

W = qU

where W is the amount of work done, q is the unit charge of the ion, and U is the potential difference.

Substituting the given values, we get:

W = 2.4 \* 1.6 \* 0.27 = 0.86 \* 1.6 = 1.33 \* 10^-3 \text{ J}

Therefore, if 2.4 \* 10^-3 \* milliamps of current flow through an electric circuit, a potential difference of 0.27 volts can do 1.33 milliamps of work.

Let's write the Nernst equation for the reduction of white phosphorus to phosphine gas:
$\frac{1}{4} \mathrm{P}_{4}(s, \text { white })+3 \mathrm{H}^{+}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \underset{\text { Phosphine }}{\mathrm{PH}_{3}(g)} \quad E^{\circ}=-0.046 \mathrm{~V}$【analysis】This problem mainly examines the application of Nernst equation and the standard electrode potential of chemical reactions
【answer】We omit solids from the reaction quotient, and the concentration of a gas is expressed as the pressure of the gas.Therefore, the Nernst equation is

$E=-0.046-\frac{0.05916}{3} \log \frac{P_{\mathrm{PH}_{3}}}{\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]^{3}}$
【In summary，$E=-0.046-\frac{0.05916}{3} \log \frac{P_{\mathrm{PH}_{3}}}{\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]^{3}}$.】

Let's write the Nernst equation for the reduction of white phosphorus to phosphine gas:
$\frac{1}{4} \mathrm{P}_{4}(s, \text { white })+3 \mathrm{H}^{+}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \underset{\text { Phosphine }}{\mathrm{PH}_{3}(g)} \quad E^{\circ}=-0.046 \mathrm{~V}$The Nernst equation for the reduction of white phosphorus to phosphine gas can be written as:

$\frac{1}{4} \mathrm{P}_{4}(s, \text { white })+3 \mathrm{H}^{+}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \underset{\text { Phosphine }}{\mathrm{PH}_{3}(g)} \quad E^{\circ}=-0.046 \mathrm{~V}$

Where,

* $\frac{1}{4} \mathrm{P}_{4}(s, \text { white })}$ represents the amount of white phosphorus (phosphorus atom) that is reduced to phosphine gas (PH3).
* $3 \mathrm{H}^{+}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-}$ represents the number of protons (H+) and electrons (e-) remaining after the reduction process.
* $\underset{\text { Phosphine }}{\mathrm{PH}_{3}(g)}$ represents the amount of phosphine gas (PH3) produced.
* $E^{\circ}$ is the standard Gibbs energy (ΔG°), which is the energy change for the reaction per unit of reactants and products.

The Gibbs free energy change for the reaction can be calculated using the standard Gibbs free energy equation:

ΔG° = ΔH° - TΔS°

Where,

* ΔH° is the enthalpy change (ΔH) of the reaction, which is the change in the enthalpy of the products (PH3)

Let's write the Nernst equation for the reduction of white phosphorus to phosphine gas:
$\frac{1}{4} \mathrm{P}_{4}(s, \text { white })+3 \mathrm{H}^{+}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \underset{\text { Phosphine }}{\mathrm{PH}_{3}(g)} \quad E^{\circ}=-0.046 \mathrm{~V}$The Nernst equation for the reduction of white phosphorus to phosphine gas can be written as:

$\frac{1}{4} \mathrm{P}_{4}(s, \text { white })+3 \mathrm{H}^{+}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \underset{\text { Phosphine }}{\mathrm{PH}_{3}(g)} \quad E^{\circ}=-0.046 \mathrm{~V}$

Where,

* $\frac{1}{4} \mathrm{P}_{4}(s, \text { white })}$ represents the forward reaction rate and the solid phosphorus (white phosphorus) is the reactant.
* $3 \mathrm{H}^{+}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-}$ represents the forward reaction rate and the hydrogen ions (H+) and electrons (e-) are the reactants.
* $\underset{\text { Phosphine }}{\mathrm{PH}_{3}(g)}$ represents the product and the phosphine gas (g) is the product.
* $E^{\circ}=-0.046 \mathrm{~V}$ is the enthalpy change (ΔH) of the reaction and it is used to calculate the standard Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) of the reaction.

If we multiply a half-reaction by any factor,  $E^{\circ}$  does not change. However, the factor  n  before the log term and the form of the reaction quotient,  $Q$ , do change. Let's write the Nernst equation for the reaction in the preceding example, multiplied by 2 :
$\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{P}_{4}(s, \text { white })+6 \mathrm{H}^{+}+6 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{PH}_{3}(g) \quad E^{\circ}=-0.046 \mathrm{~V}$【analysis】This problem mainly examines the application of Nernst equation and the standard electrode potential of chemical reactions
【answer】This problem is solved using the Nernst equation and knowledge of the standard electrode potential of chemical reactions

$E=-0.046-\frac{0.05916}{6} \log \frac{P_{\mathrm{PH}_{3}}^{2}}{\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]^{6}}$

Even though this Nernst equation does not look like the one in the preceding example, Box 13-2 shows that the numerical value of  $E$  is unchanged. The squared term in the reaction quotient cancels the doubled value of  $n$  in front of the log term.
【In summary，$E=-0.046-\frac{0.05916}{6} \log \frac{P_{\mathrm{PH}_{3}}^{2}}{\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]^{6}}$.】

If we multiply a half-reaction by any factor,  $E^{\circ}$  does not change. However, the factor  n  before the log term and the form of the reaction quotient,  $Q$ , do change. Let's write the Nernst equation for the reaction in the preceding example, multiplied by 2 :
$\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{P}_{4}(s, \text { white })+6 \mathrm{H}^{+}+6 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{PH}_{3}(g) \quad E^{\circ}=-0.046 \mathrm{~V}$The Nernst equation for the reaction with a half-reaction is:

$\frac{dE^{\circ}}{dt} = \frac{1}{2} \frac{\mathrm{d}Q}{dt} + \frac{3}{2} \frac{\mathrm{d}H}{dt} + \frac{3}{2} \frac{\mathrm{d}e^{-}}{dt}$

If we multiply the equation by 2, we get:

$\frac{2}{E^{\circ}} \frac{\mathrm{d}Q}{dt} + 3 \frac{\mathrm{d}H}{dt} + 3 \frac{\mathrm{d}e^{-}}{dt} = 0.092 \mathrm{~V/s}$

As you can see, the factor 2 changes the expression of the rate equations, but the Nernst equation itself remains the same. This means that the rate constant,  $K_{E}$, remains constant as well.

If we multiply a half-reaction by any factor,  $E^{\circ}$  does not change. However, the factor  n  before the log term and the form of the reaction quotient,  $Q$ , do change. Let's write the Nernst equation for the reaction in the preceding example, multiplied by 2 :
$\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{P}_{4}(s, \text { white })+6 \mathrm{H}^{+}+6 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{PH}_{3}(g) \quad E^{\circ}=-0.046 \mathrm{~V}$The Nernst equation for the reaction with a half-reaction is given by:

$\frac{dE^{\circ}}{dt} = \frac{1}{2} \frac{\mathrm{d}Q}{dE} \frac{\mathrm{d}E}{dT} \frac{\mathrm{d}T}{dV}$

where $Q$ is the reaction quotient, $E$ is the standard potential, $T$ is the temperature, and $V$ is the volume. If we multiply the equation by 2, we get:

$\frac{2}{E} \frac{\mathrm{d}E}{dT} \frac{\mathrm{d}T}{dV} = \frac{1}{2} \frac{\mathrm{d}Q}{dE} \frac{\mathrm{d}E}{dT} \frac{\mathrm{d}T}{dV}$

The factor $2$ in the left-hand side and right-hand side disappeared, and the right-hand side was multiplied by $\frac{1}{2}$ to平衡 it. The result is:

$\frac{\mathrm{d}E}{dT} = - \frac{1}{2} \frac{\mathrm{d}Q}{dE} \frac{\mathrm{d}E}{dT}$

This equation shows that the rate of change of the standard potential (E) with respect to temperature (T) is equal to the negative of the rate of change of the reaction quotient (Q) with respect to the standard potential (E). The Nernst equation for a reaction with a half-reaction can be written in terms of the reactants and products concentrations, the rate of the reaction, and the temperature.

Find the equilibrium constant for the reaction
$\mathrm{Cu}(s)+2 \mathrm{Fe}^{3+} \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{Fe}^{2+}+\mathrm{Cu}^{2+}$【analysis】This problem mainly examines the electrochemical reaction and the standard electrode potential of the reaction
【answer】This problem can be solved using the Nernst equation

Divide the reaction into two half-reactions found in Appendix  $\mathrm{H}$:
$\begin{array}{clrl}
2 \mathrm{Fe}^{3+}+2 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{Fe}^{2+} & E_{+}^{\circ}=0.771 \mathrm{~V} \\
\mathrm{Cu}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Cu}(s) & E_{-}^{\circ}=0.339 \mathrm{~V} \\
\hline \mathrm{Cu}(s)+2 \mathrm{Fe}^{3+} \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{Fe}^{2+}+\mathrm{Cu}^{2+} & &
\end{array}$
Then find  $E^{\circ}$  for the net reaction
$E^{\circ}=E_{+}^{\circ}-E_{-}^{\circ}=0.771-0.339=0.432 \mathrm{~V}$
and compute the equilibrium constant with Equation 13-24:
$K=10^{(2)(0.432) /(0.05916)}=4 \times 10^{14}$
A modest value of  $E^{\circ}$  produces a large equilibrium constant. The value of  K  is correctly expressed with one significant figure, because  $E^{\circ}$  has three digits. Two are used for the exponent (14), and one is left for the multiplier (4).
【In summary，$K=4 \times 10^{14}$.】

Find the equilibrium constant for the reaction
$\mathrm{Cu}(s)+2 \mathrm{Fe}^{3+} \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{Fe}^{2+}+\mathrm{Cu}^{2+}$The equilibrium constant for a chemical reaction can be calculated using the Le Chatelier原理. This involves holding the other variables constant and adjusting the concentration of one variable to see if the reaction shifts in response. The equilibrium constant is the ratio of the concentrations of the products to the concentrations of the reactants, multiplied by the product concentration squared.

For the reaction:

Cu(s) + 2Fe3+ ⇌ 2Fe2+ + Cu2+

To find the equilibrium constant, we can start by holding the concentration of Cu(s) constant and adjusting the concentrations of Fe3+ and Fe2+. Let's say we start with [Fe3+] = 1 mol/L and [Fe2+] = 0 mol/L. We can then calculate the concentrations of Cu2+ and Cu(s) by using the reaction equation and the initial concentrations.

[Cu2+] = [Fe3+] x [Cu(s)] / 2 = 1 mol/L x 1 / 2 = 0.5 mol/L

[Cu(s)] = [Cu2+] / [Cu(s)] = 0.5 mol/L / 1 mol/L = 0.5 mol/L

Now we can calculate the concentrations of Fe2+ by using the reaction equation and the initial and current concentrations.

[Fe2+] = [Cu(s)] x [Fe3+] x 2 / 1 = 0.5 mol/L x 1 mol/L x 2 / 1 = 1 mol/L

[Fe3+] = [Fe2+] x 2 / 1 = 1 mol/L x 2 / 1 = 2 mol/L

We can see that the concentration of Fe3+ is higher than the concentration of Fe2+, which is not desirable for the reaction. This means that the reaction is not in equilibrium and we need to adjust the initial concentrations or the concentration of one of the other reactants to shift the reaction in the direction of the equilibrium.

To simplify the problem, we can assume that the reaction is at equilibrium and the concentrations of all species are constant. In this case, the equilibrium constant can be calculated using the following formula:

K = c^2 (产物) / c^2 (反应物)

where c is the concentration of each species.

K = [Fe2+]^2 / [Fe3+]^2 = (1 mol/L)^2 / (2 mol/L)^2 = 1 / 4 = 0.25

Therefore, the equilibrium constant for the reaction Cu(s) + 2Fe3+ ⇌ 2Fe2+ + Cu2+ is 0.25.

E_{-}^{\circ}=\text { ? } \\
\mathrm{Ni}^{2+}+2 \text { glycine }{ }^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Ni}(\text { glycine })_{2} \\
E^{\circ}=? \quad K=1.2 \times 10^{11} \\
\end{array}$
We know that  $E_{+}^{\circ}-E_{-}^{\circ}$  must equal  $E^{\circ}$ , so we can deduce the value of  $E_{-}^{\circ}$  if we can find  $E^{\circ}$ . But  $E^{\circ}$  can be determined from the equilibrium constant for the net reaction:
$E^{\circ}=\frac{0.05916}{n} \log K=\frac{0.05916}{2} \log \left(1.2 \times 10^{11}\right)=0.328 \mathrm{~V}$

$E_{-}^{\circ}=E_{+}^{\circ}-E^{\circ}=-0.236-0.328=-0.564 \mathrm{~V}$

From the formation constant of Ni(glycine)$_2$ plus $E^{0}$ for the $\mathrm{Ni}^{2+}\mid\mathrm{Ni}(s)$ couple,
$\begin{aligned}\mathrm{Ni}^{2+}+2\:\mathrm{glycine}^{-}&\implies\mathrm{Ni}(\mathrm{glycine})_{2}\quad K\equiv\beta_{2}=1.2\times10^{11}\\\mathrm{Ni}^{2+}+2\mathrm{e}^{-}&\implies\mathrm{Ni}(s)\quad E^{\circ}=-0.236\:\mathrm{V}\end{aligned}$
deduce the value of  $E^{\circ}$  for the reaction
$\mathrm{Ni}(\text { glycine })_{2}+2 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Ni}(s)+2 \text { glycine }^{-}$ (13-25)The value of $E^{\circ}$ for the reaction $\mathrm{Ni}(\text{glycine})_{2}+2\mathrm{e}^{-}\rightleftharpoons\mathrm{Ni}(s)+2\text{ glycine}^{-}$ can be calculated using the formation constant (K) and the given data.

The formation constant (K) for the Ni(glycine)$_2$ couple is $K\equiv\beta_{2}=1.2\times10^{11}$. The value of K for the Ni(s)$_2$ couple is given as $E^{\circ}=-0.236\:\mathrm{V}$, but this value is for the formation of Ni(s)$_2$ from Ni(s) and not for the reaction you provided.

The reaction you provided is a first-order reaction, so the rate constant (k) can be calculated using the formula:

k = (k_1 \times k_2)^0.5

where k_1 and k_2 are the rate constants for the two reactants and the product, respectively.

Since the two reactants are the same (Ni(glycine)$_2$ and Ni(s)), their rate constants are the same:

k = k_1^0.5 = (K$\cdot$K)$\cdot$(1/2)^0.5 = (1.2\times10^{11} $\cdot$ 1.2\times10^{11})^0.5 = 7.2\times10^9\ \mathrm{mol^{-1}\cdot s^{-1}}$

The rate constant for the product (Ni(s)$_2$) is given as $E^{\circ}=-0.236\:\mathrm{V}$, so the rate constant for the reaction can be calculated as:

k = k_2 = k$\cdot$(1/2)^0.5 = (7.2\times10^9)$\cdot$(1/2)^0.5 = 3.6\times10^9\ \mathrm{mol^{-1}\cdot s^{-1}}$

The value of $E^{\circ}$ can be calculated using the formula:

$E^{\circ}$ = (k - k_2) / (1 + (k / k_2)^0.5)

where k and k_2 are the rate constants for the reactants and the product, respectively.

Substituting the values of k and k_2, we get:

$E^{\circ}$ = (3.6\times10^9 - 3.6\times10^9) / (1 + (3.6\times10^9 / 7.2\times10^9)^0.5) = 3.6\times10^9\ \mathrm{mol^{-1}\cdot s^{-1}}$

Therefore, the value of $E^{\circ}$ for the reaction $\mathrm{Ni}(\text{glycine})_{2}+2\mathrm{e}^{-}\rightleftharpoons\mathrm{Ni}(s)+2\text{ glycine}^{-}$ is $3.6\times10^9\ \mathrm{mol^{-1}\cdot s^{-1}}$.

In olden days, mercury cells with the following chemistry were used to power heart pacemakers:
$\mathrm{Zn}(s)+\mathrm{HgO}(s) \rightarrow \mathrm{ZnO}(s)+\mathrm{Hg}(l) \quad E^{\circ}=1.35 \mathrm{~V}$
What is the cell voltage? If the power required to operate the pacemaker is  $0.0100 \mathrm{~W}$ , how many kilograms of  HgO  $(FM 216.59)$ will be consumed in 365 days? How many pounds of  HgO  is this? ($1 pound  =453.6 \mathrm{~g}$)【analysis】This problem mainly looks at the battery voltage and power calculation
【answer】This problem requires using the standard potential of the battery to calculate the battery voltage, and then using the power formula to calculate the mass of the HgO consumed

The cell voltage will be  1.35 $\mathrm{~V}$  because all activities are unity.
$\begin{array}{l}
I=\mathrm{P} / \mathrm{E}=0.0100 \mathrm{~W} / 1.35 \mathrm{~V}=7.41 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{s} \\
\mathrm{mol} \mathrm{e}^{-} / \mathrm{s}=\left(7.41 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{s}\right) /\left(9.649 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{mol}\right) \\
=7.68 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{e}^{-} / \mathrm{s}=2.42 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{e}-/ 365 \text { days } \\
=1.21 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{HgO} / 365 \text { days }=0.262 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{HgO} \\
=0.578 \mathrm{lb}
\end{array}$
【In summary，$\mathrm{mol} \mathrm{e}^{-} / \mathrm{s}=0.578 \mathrm{lb}$.】

To calculate the amount of HgO consumed in 365 days, we can use the following formula:

Amount of HgO (in kg) = Power (in W) x Time (in days) / (1000 x 365)

Plugging in the given values, we get:

Amount of HgO = 0.0100 W x 365 days / (1000 x 365) = 0.000000358 kg

To convert the kg to pounds, we can multiply by the conversion factor:

0.000000358 kg \* 453.6 g/kg = 0.0157 pounds

Therefore, if the power required to operate the pacemaker is $0.0100 \mathrm{~W}$, the cell voltage is not provided in the information given, and the amount of HgO consumed in 365 days is 0.0157 pounds.

0.0100 W \* 365 days = 3.65 kWh

The amount of O2 consumed can be calculated using the反应 for the mercury cells:

1 mol O2 = 1.35 V

The volume of O2 produced is proportional to the volume of the reactant HgO:

V(O2) = V(HgO)

The mass of O2 produced is proportional to the volume of O2 and the density of O2:

m(O2) = ρ \* V(O2)

We know that the reactant HgO is in the form of HgO(s), so we need to calculate the volume of reactant HgO. The volume of a sphere can be calculated as:

V(HgO) = (4/3)πr^3

We do not know the radius of the sphere, so we can rearrange the formula to solve for r:

r = (3V(HgO))^(1/3)

Substituting this expression for r into the formula for O2 production:

m(O2) = ρ \* V(O2) = 1.32 \* (4/3)πr^3 \* 3.65 kWh

Solving for r:

r = (3 \* 3.65 kWh)^(1/3) / (1.32 \* 1.35)

r = 0.0062 m

The volume of O2 produced is 0.0062 m^3.

The mass of HgO can be calculated using the formula for the density of HgO:

d(HgO) = 453.6 g/mol

m(HgO) = 0.0062 m^3 \* 453.6 g/mol = 27.65 g

The mass of HgO is 27.65 grams.

Calculate  $E^{\circ}$  and  K  for each of the following reactions.
(a)  $\mathrm{I}_{2}(s)+5 \mathrm{Br}_{2}(a q)+6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{IO}_{3}^{-}+10 \mathrm{Br}^{-}+12 \mathrm{H}^{+}$

(c)  $\mathrm{Mg}(s)+\mathrm{Cl}_{2}(g) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Mg}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$ 
(d)  $5 \mathrm{MnO}_{2}(s)+4 \mathrm{H}^{+} \rightleftharpoons 3 \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$ 
(e)  $\mathrm{Ag}^{+}+2 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Ag}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}^{3-}$ 
(f)  $\mathrm{CuI}(s) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Cu}^{+}+\mathrm{I}^{-}$【analysis】This problem is mainly concerned with the calculation of the standard electrode potential and equilibrium constant of chemical reactions
【answer】This problem requires using the Nernst equation to calculate the standard potential $E^{\circ}$and K values for each reaction

$\text { (a) } \begin{array}{l}
5 \mathrm{Br}_{2}(a q)+10 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons 10 \mathrm{Br}^{-} \\
-2 \mathrm{IO}_{3}^{-}+12 \mathrm{H}^{+}+10 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{I}_{2}(s)+6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}
\end{array} \\
\frac{\mathrm{I}_{2}(s)+5 \mathrm{Br}_{2}(a q)+6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{IO}_{3}^{-}+10 \mathrm{Br}^{-}+12 \mathrm{H}^{+}}{E_{+}^{\circ}=1.098 \mathrm{~V}} \\
\frac{E_{-}^{\circ}=1.210 \mathrm{~V}}{E^{\circ}=1.098-1.210=-0.112 \mathrm{~V}} \\
K=10^{10(-0.112) / 0.05916}=1 \times 10^{-19}$
(b)$\begin{array}{l}
\mathrm{Cr}^{2+}+2 e^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Cr}(s) \\
\mathrm{Fe}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Fe}(s) \\
\overline{\mathrm{Cr}^{2+}+\mathrm{Fe}(s) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Cr}(s)+\mathrm{Fe}^{2+}} \\
E_{+}^{\circ}=-0.89 \mathrm{~V} \\
E_{-}^{\circ}=-0.44 \mathrm{~V} \\
\overline{E^{\circ}}=-0.89-(-0.44)=-0.45 \mathrm{~V} \\
K=10^{2(-0.45) \text { N0.059 } 16}=6 \times 10^{-16} \\
\end{array}$
(c)$\begin{array}{l}
\mathrm{Cl}_{2}(\mathrm{~g})+2 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{Cl}^{-} \\
\mathrm{Mg}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Mg}(s) \\
\mathrm{Mg}(s)+\mathrm{Cl}_{2}(g) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Mg}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{Cl}^{-} \\
E_{+}^{\circ}=1.360 \mathrm{~V} \\
E_{-}^{\circ}=-2.360 \mathrm{~V} \\
\overline{E^{\circ}=1.360-(-2.360)=3.720 \mathrm{~V}} \\
K=10^{2(3.720) / 0.05916}=6 \times 10^{125} \\
\end{array}$
(d)_$3\left[\mathrm{MnO}_{2}(s)+4 \mathrm{H}^{+}+2 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\right] $
$\frac{2\left[\mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}+4 \mathrm{H}^{+}+3 e^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{MnO}_{2}(s)+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\right]}{5 \mathrm{MnO}_{2}(s)+4 \mathrm{H}^{+} \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}+3 \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}}$
$\begin{array}{l}
E_{+}^{\circ}=1.230 \mathrm{~V} \\
\frac{E_{-}^{\circ}=1.692 \mathrm{~V}}{E^{\circ}=1.230-1.692=-0.462 \mathrm{~V}} \\
K=10^{6(-0.462) / 0.05916}=1 \times 10^{-47}
\end{array}$
An alternate way to answer (d) is
$\begin{array}{l}
-5\left[\mathrm{MnO}_{2}(s)+4 \mathrm{H}^{+}+2 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\right] \\
2\left[\mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}+8 \mathrm{H}^{+}+5 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}+4 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\right] \\
5 \mathrm{MnO}_{2}(s)+4 \mathrm{H}^{+} \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}+3 \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \\
E_{+}^{\circ}=1.230 \mathrm{~V} \\
E_{-}^{\circ}=1.507 \mathrm{~V} \\
\overline{E^{\circ}=1.230-1.507=-0.277 \mathrm{~V}} \\
K=10^{10(-0.277) / 0.05916}=2 \times 10^{-47} \\
\end{array}$
$\begin{array}{l}
\text { (e) } \mathrm{Ag}^{+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Ag}(s) \\
\frac{\mathrm{Ag}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}^{3-}+\mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Ag}(s)+2 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}}{\mathrm{Ag}^{+}+2 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Ag}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}^{3-}} \\
E_{+}^{\circ}=0.799 \mathrm{~V} \\

Calculate  $E^{\circ}$  and  K  for each of the following reactions.
(a)  $\mathrm{I}_{2}(s)+5 \mathrm{Br}_{2}(a q)+6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{IO}_{3}^{-}+10 \mathrm{Br}^{-}+12 \mathrm{H}^{+}$ 
(b)  $\mathrm{Cr}^{2+}+\mathrm{Fe}(s) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Fe}^{2+}+\mathrm{Cr}(s)$
(c)  $\mathrm{Mg}(s)+\mathrm{Cl}_{2}(g) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Mg}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$ 
(d)  $5 \mathrm{MnO}_{2}(s)+4 \mathrm{H}^{+} \rightleftharpoons 3 \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$ 
(e)  $\mathrm{Ag}^{+}+2 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Ag}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}^{3-}$ 
(f)  $\mathrm{CuI}(s) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Cu}^{+}+\mathrm{I}^{-}$(a)

首先，我们需要将反应方程式中的化学式和反应物中的原子数目转化为摩尔数。对于反应物中的$\mathrm{I}$和$\mathrm{Br}$，我们可以将其摩尔数设为$x$和$y$，则反应方程式可写为：

$$\mathrm{I_{2}(s)} + 5\mathrm{Br_{2}(a q)} + 6\mathrm{H_{2}O} \rightleftharpoons 2\mathrm{IO_{3}^{-}} + 10\mathrm{Br^{-}} + 12\mathrm{H^{+}}$$

根据化学式，$\mathrm{I_{2}(s)}$的摩尔数为$x$，$\mathrm{Br_{2}(a q)}$的摩尔数为$5x$，$\mathrm{H_{2}O}$的摩尔数为$6x$。对于$\mathrm{Br^{-}}$和$\mathrm{IO_{3}^{-}}$，它们的摩尔数分别为$10x$和$2x$。对于$\mathrm{H^{+}}$，它的摩尔数为$12x$。因此，反应物中的原子数目为：

$$\begin{aligned} &\text{原子数(I_{2})} = x \\ &\text{原子数(Br_{2})} = 5x \\ &\text{原子数(H_{2}O)} = 6x \\ &\text{原子数(Br^{-})} = 10x \\ &\text{原子数(IO_{3}^{-})} = 2x \\ &\text{原子数(H^{+})} = 12x \end{aligned}$$

根据化学方程式，反应物中的原子数目与生成物中的原子数目相等。因此，生成物中的原子数目为：

$$\begin{aligned} &\text{原子数(IO_{3}^{-})} = 2x \\ &\text{原子数(Br^{-})} = 10x \\ &\text{原子数(Mn^{2+})} = 3x \\ &\text{原子数(MnO_{4}^{-})} = 2x \\ &\text{原子数(H_{2}O)} = 12x \end{aligned}$$

生成物中的原子数目与反应物中的原子数目相等。因此，我们可以得到反应的平衡常数：

$$K=\frac{[\mathrm{IO_{3}^{-}}][\mathrm{Br^{-}}]^{10}}{[\mathrm{I_{2}}][\mathrm{Br_{2}}]^{5}}=\frac{2x}{x^{5}\cdot5x^{5}}=\frac{2}{350}$$

根据反应方程式，$\mathrm{K}$的值为：

$$K=\frac{[\mathrm{IO_{3}^{-}}]^{2}[\mathrm{Br^{-}}]^{10}}{[\mathrm{I_{2}}]^{5}[\mathrm{Br_{2}}]^{5}}=\frac{2x^{2}\cdot10x^{10}}{x^{5}\cdot5x^{5}}=\frac{4x^{2}}{x^{2}}=4$$

因此，$\mathrm{K}$的值为$4$。

(b)

反应方程式为：

$$\mathrm{Cr^{2+}}+\mathrm{Fe(s)} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Fe^{2+}}+\mathrm{Cr(s)}$$

根据反应方程式，$\mathrm{Cr^{2+}}$和$\mathrm{Fe}$的摩尔数分别为$x$和$y$，$\mathrm{Fe^{2+}}$和$\mathrm{Cr}$的摩尔数分别为$z$和$w$。因此，反应物中的原子数目为：

$$\begin{aligned} &\text{原子数(Cr^{2+})} = x \\ &\text{原子数(Fe)} = y \\ &\text{原子数(Cr)} = w \\ &\text{原子数(Fe^{2+})} = z \\ &\text{原子数(I)} = 0 \\ &\text{原子数(O)} = 0 \end{aligned}$$

生成物中的原子数目为：

$$\begin{aligned} &\text{原子数(Fe^{2+})} = z \\ &\text{原子数(Cr^{2+})} = x-z \\ &\text{原子数(I)} = 2z \\ &\text{原子数(O)} = 2y \end{aligned}$$

生成物中的原子数目与反应物中的原子数目相等。因此，我们可以得到反应的平衡常数：

$$K=\frac{[\mathrm{Fe^{2+}}]^{2}}{[\mathrm{Cr^{2+}}]y^{2}}=\frac{z^{2}}{(x-z)y^{2}}=\frac{z^{2}}{x^{2}-2xyz}$$

根据反应方程式，$\mathrm{K}$的值为：

$$K=\frac{[\mathrm{Fe^{2+}}]^{2}}{[\mathrm{Cr^{2+}}]y^{2}}=\frac{z^{2}}{x^{2}-2xyz}=1$$

因此，$\mathrm{K}$的值为$1$。

(c)

反应方程式为：

$$\mathrm{Mg(s)}+\mathrm{Cl_{2}(g)} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Mg^{2+}}+2\mathrm{Cl^{-}}$$

根据反应方程式，$\mathrm{Mg}$和$\mathrm{Cl_{2}}$的摩尔数分别为$x$和$y$，$\mathrm{Mg^{2+}}$和$\mathrm{Cl^{-}}$的摩尔数分别为$z$和$w$。因此，反应物中的原子数目为：

$$\begin{aligned} &\text{原子数(Mg)} = x \\ &\text{原子数(Cl_{2})} = y \\ &\text{原子数(Mg^{2+})} = z \\ &\text{原子数(Cl^{-})} = w \\ &\text{原子数(O)} = 0 \end{aligned}$$

生成物中的原子数目为：

$$\begin{aligned} &\text{原子数(Mg^{2+})} = z \\ &\text{原子数(Cl^{-})} = w \\ &\text{原子数(O)} = 0 \end{aligned}$$

生成物中的原子数目与反应物中的原子数目相等。因此，我们可以得到反应的平衡常数：

$$K=\frac{[\mathrm{Mg^{2+}}]^{2}}{[\mathrm{Cl_{2}}]w^{2}}=\frac{z^{2}}{w^{2}}=\frac{z^{2}}{y^{2}}$$

根据反应方程式，$\mathrm{K}$的值为：

$$K=\frac{[\mathrm{Mg^{2+}}]^{2}}{[\mathrm{Cl_{2}}]w^{2}}=\frac{z^{2}}{w^{2}}=1$$

因此，$\mathrm{K}$的值为$1$。

(d)

反应方程式为：

$$5\mathrm{MnO_{2}(s)}+4\mathrm{H^{+}} \rightleftharpoons 3\mathrm{Mn^{2+}}+2\mathrm{MnO_{4}^{-}}+2\mathrm{H_{2}O}$$

根据反应方程式，$\mathrm{MnO_{2}}$和$\mathrm{H^{+}}$的摩尔数分别为$5x$和$4y$，$\mathrm{Mn^{2+}}$和$\mathrm{MnO_{4}^{-}}$的摩尔数分别为$3x$和$2y$，$\mathrm{H_{2}O}$的摩尔数为$2x$。因此，反应物中的原子数目为：

$$\begin{aligned} &\text{原子数(MnO_{2})} = 5x \\ &\text{原子数(H^{+})} = 4y \\ &\text{原子数(Mn^{2+})} = 3x \\ &\text{原子数(MnO_{4}^{-})} = 2y \\ &\text{原子数(H_{2}O}) = 2x \end{aligned}$$

生成物中的原子数目为：

$$\begin{aligned} &\text{原子数(Mn^{2+})} = 3x \\ &\text{原子数(MnO_{4}^{-})} = 2y \\ &\text{原子数(H_{2}O}) = 2x \end{aligned}$$

生成物中的原子数目与反应物中的原子数目相等。因此，我们可以得到反应的平衡常数：

$$K=\frac{[\mathrm{Mn^{2+}}]^{3}}{[\mathrm{MnO_{2}}]^{5}[\mathrm{H^{+}}]^{4}}=\frac{27x^{3}}{x^{5}\cdot4^{4}}=\frac{27}{256}$$

因此，$\mathrm{K}$的值为$\frac{27}{256}$。

(e)

反应方程式为：

$$\mathrm{Ag^{+}}+2\mathrm{S_{2}O_{3}^{2-}} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Ag}\left(\mathrm{S_{2}O_{3}}^{2-}\right)_{2}^{3-}$$

根据反应方程式，$\mathrm{Ag^{+}}$和$\mathrm{S_{2}O_{3}^{2-}}$的摩尔数分别为$x$和$2y$，$\mathrm{Ag}\left(\mathrm{S_{2}O_{3}}^{2-}\right)_{2}^{3-}$的摩尔数为$z$。因此，反应物中的原子数目为：

$$\begin{aligned} &\text{原子数(Ag^{+})} = x \\ &\text{原子数(S_{2}O_{3}^{2-})} = 2y \\ &\text{原子数(Ag)} = z \\ &\text{原子数(O)} = 0 \end{aligned}$$

生成物中的原子数目为：

$$\begin{aligned} &\text{原子数(Ag)} = z \\ &\text{原子数(S_{2}O_{3}^{2-})} = 2y \\ &\text{原子数(O)} = 0 \end{aligned}$$

生成物中的原子数目与反应物中的原子数目相等。因此，我们可以得到反应的平衡常数：

$$K=\frac{[\mathrm{Ag}]^{1}[(\mathrm{S_{2}O_{3}}^{2-})^{2}]}{[\mathrm{Ag^{+}}]^{1}[(\mathrm{S_{2}O_{3}}^{2-})^{2}]}=\frac{z}{x^{2}}$$

因此，$\mathrm{K}$的值为$\frac{z}{x^{2}}$。

(f)

反应方程式为：

$$\mathrm{CuI(s)} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Cu^{+}}+\mathrm{I^{-}}$$

根据反应方程式，$\mathrm{CuI}$和$\mathrm{I^{-}}$的摩尔数分别为$x$和$y$，$\mathrm{Cu^{+}}$和$\mathrm{I^{-}}$的摩尔数分别为$z$和$w$。因此，反应物中的原子数目为：

$$\begin{aligned} &\text{原子数(CuI)} = x \\ &\text{原子数(I^{-})} = y \\ &\text{原子数(Cu^{+})} = z \\ &\text{原子数(O)} = 0 \end{aligned}$$

生成物中的原子数目为：

$$\begin{aligned} &\text{原子数(Cu^{+})} = z \\ &\text{原子数(I^{-})} = y \\ &\text{原子数(O)} = 0 \end{aligned}$$

生成物中的原子数目与反应物中的原子数目相等。因此，我们可以得到反应的平衡常数：

$$K=\frac{[\mathrm{Cu^{+}}]^{1}[(\mathrm{I^{-}})^{1}]}{[\mathrm{CuI}]^{1}}=\frac{z}{x}$$

因此，$\mathrm{K}$的值为$\frac{z}{x}$。

Calculate  $E^{\circ}$  and  K  for each of the following reactions.
(a)  $\mathrm{I}_{2}(s)+5 \mathrm{Br}_{2}(a q)+6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{IO}_{3}^{-}+10 \mathrm{Br}^{-}+12 \mathrm{H}^{+}$ 
(b)  $\mathrm{Cr}^{2+}+\mathrm{Fe}(s) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Fe}^{2+}+\mathrm{Cr}(s)$
(c)  $\mathrm{Mg}(s)+\mathrm{Cl}_{2}(g) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Mg}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$ 
(d)  $5 \mathrm{MnO}_{2}(s)+4 \mathrm{H}^{+} \rightleftharpoons 3 \mathrm{Mn}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{MnO}_{4}^{-}+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$ 
(e)  $\mathrm{Ag}^{+}+2 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Ag}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}^{3-}$ 
(f)  $\mathrm{CuI}(s) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Cu}^{+}+\mathrm{I}^{-}$(a) 首先，我们需要将反应式中的物质量乘以反应系数，以得到反应物的摩尔数。对于反应式$\mathrm{I_{2}(s)+5Br_{2}(aq)+6H_{2}O \rightleftharpoons 2IO_{3}^{-}(aq)+10Br^{-}(aq)+12H^{+}(aq)$，我们有：

$\mathrm{I_{2}(s) : 1}$

$\mathrm{Br_{2}(aq) : 5}$

$\mathrm{H_{2}O(l) : 6}$

$\mathrm{I_{2}(aq) : 2}$

$\mathrm{Br_{2}(aq) : 10}$

$\mathrm{IO_{3}^{-}(aq) : 1}$

$\mathrm{Br^{-}(aq) : 10}$

$\mathrm{H^{+}(aq) : 12}$

接下来，我们需要计算反应物的摩尔浓度。对于每个物质，我们需要将其摩尔数除以反应容积（在水中），以得到摩尔浓度。我们假设反应容积为1升，即$1000$ 毫升。

$\mathrm{I_{2}(s) : 1/1000 = 0.01}$

$\mathrm{Br_{2}(aq) : 5/1000 = 0.05}$

$\mathrm{H_{2}O(l) : 6/1000 = 0.06}$

$\mathrm{I_{2}(aq) : 2/1000 = 0.02}$

$\mathrm{Br_{2}(aq) : 10/1000 = 0.1}$

$\mathrm{IO_{3}^{-}(aq) : 1/1000 = 0.01}$

$\mathrm{Br^{-}(aq) : 10/1000 = 0.1}$

$\mathrm{H^{+}(aq) : 12/1000 = 0.12}$

现在，我们可以使用反应物的摩尔浓度来计算反应的速率常数（K）。对于该反应，反应速率常数可以定义为反应物摩尔浓度乘以反应物系数之积，除以产物摩尔浓度乘以产物系数之积。在这个反应中，反应物是$\mathrm{I_{2}(s)}$和$\mathrm{Br_{2}(aq)}$，产物是$\mathrm{IO_{3}^{-}(aq)}$和$\mathrm{Br^{-}(aq)}$。因此，反应速率常数可以计算为：

$\mathrm{K = \dfrac{(0.01 \times 2) \times (0.01 \times 12)}{(0.02 \times 10) \times (0.1 \times 10)} = 4}$

因此，反应$\mathrm{I_{2}(s)+5Br_{2}(aq)+6H_{2}O \rightleftharpoons 2IO_{3}^{-}(aq)+10Br^{-}(aq)+12H^{+}(aq)}$的速率为$4$。

(b) 对于反应$\mathrm{Cr^{2+}+\mathrm{Fe}(s) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Fe^{2+}+\mathrm{Cr}(s)}$，我们同样需要计算反应物的摩尔数。对于每个物质，我们有：

$\mathrm{Cr^{2+}(aq) : 1}$

$\mathrm{Fe(s) : 1}$

$\mathrm{Fe^{2+}(aq) : 1}$

$\mathrm{Cr(s) : 1}$

现在，我们需要计算反应物的摩尔浓度。对于每个物质，我们需要将其摩尔数除以反应容积（在水中），以得到摩尔浓度。我们假设反应容积为1升，即$1000$ 毫升。

$\mathrm{Cr^{2+}(aq) : 1/1000 = 0.01}$

$\mathrm{Fe(s) : 1/1000 = 0.01}$

$\mathrm{Fe^{2+}(aq) : 1/1000 = 0.01}$

$\mathrm{Cr(s) : 1/1000 = 0.01}$

现在，我们可以使用反应物的摩尔浓度来计算反应的速率常数（K）。对于该反应，反应速率常数可以定义为反应物摩尔浓度乘以反应物系数之积，除以产物摩尔浓度乘以产物系数之积。在这个反应中，反应物是$\mathrm{Cr^{2+}(aq)}$和$\mathrm{Fe(s)}$，产物是$\mathrm{Fe^{2+}(aq)}$和$\mathrm{Cr(s)}$。因此，反应速率常数可以计算为：

$\mathrm{K = \dfrac{(0.01 \times 1) \times (0.01 \times 1)}{(0.01 \times 1) \times (0.01 \times 1)} = 1}$

因此，反应$\mathrm{Cr^{2+}(aq)+Fe(s) \rightleftharpoons Fe^{2+}(aq)+Cr(s)}$的速率为$1$。

(c) 对于反应$\mathrm{Mg(s)+\mathrm{Cl}_{2}(g) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Mg}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{Cl}^{-}$，我们同样需要计算反应物的摩尔数。对于每个物质，我们有：

$\mathrm{Mg(s) : 1}$

$\mathrm{Cl_{2}(g) : 1}$

$\mathrm{Mg^{2+}(aq) : 2}$

$\mathrm{Cl^{-}(aq) : 2}$

现在，我们需要计算反应物的摩尔浓度。对于每个物质，我们需要将其摩尔数除以反应容积（在水中），以得到摩尔浓度。我们假设反应容积为1升，即$1000$ 毫升。

$\mathrm{Mg(s) : 1/1000 = 0.01}$

$\mathrm{Cl_{2}(g) : 1/1000 = 0.01}$

$\mathrm{Mg^{2+}(aq) : 2/1000 = 0.002}$

$\mathrm{Cl^{-}(aq) : 2/1000 = 0.002}$

现在，我们可以使用反应物的摩尔浓度来计算反应的速率常数（K）。对于该反应，反应速率常数可以定义为反应物摩尔浓度乘以反应物系数之积，除以产物摩尔浓度乘以产物系数之积。在这个反应中，反应物是$\mathrm{Mg(s)}$和$\mathrm{Cl_{2}(g)}$，产物是$\mathrm{Mg^{2+}(aq)}$和$\mathrm{Cl^{-}(aq)}$。因此，反应速率常数可以计算为：

$\mathrm{K = \dfrac{(0.01 \times 2) \times (0.01 \times 2)}{(0.002 \times 2) \times (0.002 \times 2)} = 2}$

因此，反应$\mathrm{Mg(s)+\mathrm{Cl}_{2}(g) \rightleftharpoons Mg^{2+}(aq)+2Cl^{-}(aq)}$的速率为$2$。

(d) 对于反应$5 \mathrm{MnO_{2}(s)+4H^{+} \rightleftharpoons 3Mn^{2+}+2MnO_{4}^{-}+2H_{2}O$，我们同样需要计算反应物的摩尔数。对于每个物质，我们有：

$\mathrm{MnO_{2}(s) : 5}$

$\mathrm{H^{+}(aq) : 4}$

$\mathrm{Mn^{2+}(aq) : 3}$

$\mathrm{MnO_{4}^{-}(aq) : 2}$

$\mathrm{H_{2}O(l) : 2}$

现在，我们需要计算反应物的摩尔浓度。对于每个物质，我们需要将其摩尔数除以反应容积（在水中），以得到摩尔浓度。我们假设反应容积为1升，即$1000$ 毫升。

$\mathrm{MnO_{2}(s) : 5/1000 = 0.05}$

$\mathrm{H^{+}(aq) : 4/1000 = 0.04}$

$\mathrm{Mn^{2+}(aq) : 3/1000 = 0.03}$

$\mathrm{MnO_{4}^{-}(aq) : 2/1000 = 0.02}$

$\mathrm{H_{2}O(l) : 2/1000 = 0.02}$

现在，我们可以使用反应物的摩尔浓度来计算反应的速率常数（K）。对于该反应，反应速率常数可以定义为反应物摩尔浓度乘以反应物系数之积，除以产物摩尔浓度乘以产物系数之积。在这个反应中，反应物是$\mathrm{MnO_{2}(s)}$和$\mathrm{H^{+}(aq)}$，产物是$\mathrm{Mn^{2+}(aq)}$、$\mathrm{MnO_{4}^{-}(aq)}$和$\mathrm{H_{2}O(l)}$。因此，反应速率常数可以计算为：

$\mathrm{K = \dfrac{(0.05 \times 3) \times (0.04)}{(0.03 \times 2) \times (0.02 \times 2)} = 15}$

因此，反应$5 \mathrm{MnO_{2}(s)+4H^{+} \rightleftharpoons 3Mn^{2+}+2MnO_{4}^{-}+2H_{2}O$的速率为$15$。

The following cell has a voltage of  $0.083 \mathrm{~V}$  :
$\mathrm{Hg}(l) \mid \mathrm{Hg}\left(\mathrm{NO}_{3}\right)_{2}(0.0010 \mathrm{M}), \mathrm{KI}(0.500 \mathrm{M}) \| \text { S.H.E. }$
From this voltage, calculate the equilibrium constant for the reaction
$\mathrm{Hg}^{2+}+4 \mathrm{I}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{HgI}_{4}^{2-}$
In  $0.5 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{KI}$ , virtually all the mercury is present as  $\mathrm{HgI}_{4}^{2-}.$【analysis】This problem focuses on electrochemistry and the application of Nernst equations
【answer】We can be solved using the Nernst equation

$2 \mathrm{H}^{+}+2 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{H}_{2}(g) \quad E_{+}^{\circ}=0 \mathrm{~V}$
$\mathrm{Hg}^{2+}+2 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Hg}(l) \quad E_{-}^{\circ}=0.852 \mathrm{~V}$
$E=\left\{\frac{-0.05916}{2} \log \frac{P_{\mathrm{H}_{2}}}{\left[\mathrm{H}^{+}\right]^{2}}\right\}-\left\{0.852-\frac{0.05916}{2} \log \frac{1}{\left[\mathrm{Hg}^{2+}\right]}\right\}$
$0.083=\left\{\frac{-0.05916}{2} \log \frac{1}{1^{2}}\right\}-\left\{0.852-\frac{0.05916}{2} \log \frac{1}{\left[\mathrm{Hg}^{2+}\right]}\right\}$
$\Rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Hg}^{2+}\right]=2.5 \times 10^{-32} \mathrm{M}$
$\left[\mathrm{HgI}_{4}^{2-}\right]=0.0010 \mathrm{M}$. To make this much $\mathrm{HgI}_{4}^{2-}$, the concentration of $\mathrm{I}^{-}$ must have been reduced from $0.500 \mathrm{M}$ to $0.496 \mathrm{M}$, because one $\mathrm{Hg}^{2+}$ ion reacts with four $\mathrm{I}^{-}$ions.
$K=\frac{\left[\mathrm{HgI}_{4}^{2-}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{Hg}^{2+}\right]\left[\mathrm{I}^{-}\right]^{4}}=\frac{(0.0010)}{\left(2.5 \times 10^{-32}\right)(0.496)^{4}}=7 \times 10^{29} $
【In summary，$K=7 \times 10^{29}$.】

The following cell has a voltage of  $0.083 \mathrm{~V}$  :
$\mathrm{Hg}(l) \mid \mathrm{Hg}\left(\mathrm{NO}_{3}\right)_{2}(0.0010 \mathrm{M}), \mathrm{KI}(0.500 \mathrm{M}) \| \text { S.H.E. }$
From this voltage, calculate the equilibrium constant for the reaction
$\mathrm{Hg}^{2+}+4 \mathrm{I}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{HgI}_{4}^{2-}$
In  $0.5 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{KI}$ , virtually all the mercury is present as  $\mathrm{HgI}_{4}^{2-}.$The equilibrium constant for the reaction $\mathrm{Hg}^{2+}+4 \mathrm{I}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{HgI}_{4}^{2-}}$ can be calculated using the Nernst equation:

$$K_e = \frac{[HgI_4^{2-}]}{[Hg^{2+}][I_-]^4}$$

Since the cell has a voltage of $0.083\ \mathrm{V}$, and the potential difference across the cell is equal to the cell voltage, we know that the concentration of $\mathrm{Hg^{2+}}$ and $\mathrm{I^{-}}$ is equal to $0.0010\ \mathrm{M}$ and $0.500\ \mathrm{M}$, respectively.

We can calculate the concentration of $\mathrm{HgI_4^{2-}}$ by using the fact that the reaction is at equilibrium, and that the concentrations of the reactants and products are equal. The concentration of $\mathrm{HgI_4^{2-}}$ is therefore equal to $0.0010\ \mathrm{M}$ (since the反应 is in the balanced state).

Substituting this value into the Nernst equation, we get:

$$K_e = \frac{[HgI_4^{2-}]}{[Hg^{2+}][I_-]^4} = \frac{0.0010}{(0.0010)^4} = 1.0\ \mathrm{M}$$

Therefore, the equilibrium constant for the reaction $\mathrm{Hg}^{2+}+4 \mathrm{I}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{HgI}_{4}^{2-}}$ is $1.0\ \mathrm{M}$.

The following cell has a voltage of  $0.083 \mathrm{~V}$  :
$\mathrm{Hg}(l) \mid \mathrm{Hg}\left(\mathrm{NO}_{3}\right)_{2}(0.0010 \mathrm{M}), \mathrm{KI}(0.500 \mathrm{M}) \| \text { S.H.E. }$
From this voltage, calculate the equilibrium constant for the reaction
$\mathrm{Hg}^{2+}+4 \mathrm{I}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{HgI}_{4}^{2-}$
In  $0.5 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{KI}$ , virtually all the mercury is present as  $\mathrm{HgI}_{4}^{2-}.$The equilibrium constant for the reaction $\mathrm{Hg}^{2+}+4\mathrm{I}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{HgI}_{4}^{2-}}$ can be calculated using the following equation:

K = ([HgI42-]^2) / ([Hg2+]^2 [I-]^4)

Since the cell has a voltage of 0.083 V, and the potential difference across the cell is equal to the cell voltage, we know that the concentration of [Hg2+] is 2.00 x 10^-3 M. To calculate the other concentrations, we can use the following equations:

[I-] = (I\_in \* V\_in) / (V\_out \* C)
[HgI42-] = (K \* [Hg2+])^2 / (C)

where I\_in is the initial concentration of I- (0.500 M), V\_in is the volume of the cell (assumed to be 100 mL), C is the concentration of the cell (2.00 x 10^-3 M), and K is the equilibrium constant.

To calculate the volume of the cell, we can use the formula:

V = (1/2) \* D \* l

where D is the cell diameter (assumed to be 100 micrometers), and l is the distance from the cell wall to the bottom of the cell (assumed to be the depth of the cell, which is equal to the height of the cell, or the distance from the bottom of the cell to the bottom of the S.H.E.).

Plugging in the values, we get:

[I-] = (0.500 \* 10^-3) / (100 \* 2.00 x 10^-3) = 2.50 x 10^-4 M

[Hg2+] = (K \* 2.00 x 10^-3)^2 / (2.00 x 10^-3) = 2.00 x 10^-5 M

[HgI42-] = (K \* 2.00 x 10^-3)^2 / (2.00 x 10^-3) = 2.00 x 10^-5 M

Now that we have all of the necessary concentrations, we can calculate the equilibrium constant using the equation:

K = [HgI42-]^2 / ([Hg2+]^2 [I-]^4) = (2.00 x 10^-5)^2 / (2.00 x 10^-5)^2 (2.50 x 10^-4)^4 = 1.6 x 10^-9

Therefore, the equilibrium constant for the reaction $\mathrm{Hg}^{2+}+4\mathrm{I}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{HgI}_{4}^{2-}}$ is 1.6 x 10^-9.

A $0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaCl}$ solution was placed in contact with a $0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaNO}_{3}$ solution. Which side of the junction is positive?【analysis】Determine the positive and negative poles after a chemical reaction
【answer】Determine based on the rate of depletion of Cl in the sodium chloride and nitrate regions

Because $\left[\mathrm{Na}^{+}\right]$is equal on both sides, there is no net diffusion of $\mathrm{Na}^{+}$across the junction. However, $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$diffuses into $\mathrm{NaNO}_{3}$, and $\mathrm{NO}_{3}^{-}$diffuses into $\mathrm{NaCl}$. The mobility of $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$is greater than that of $\mathrm{NO}_{3}^{-}$, so the $\mathrm{NaCl}$ region will be depleted of $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$faster than the $\mathrm{NaNO}_{3}$ region will be depleted of $\mathrm{NO}_{3}^{-}$. The $\mathrm{NaNO}_{3}$ side will become negative, and the $\mathrm{NaCl}$ side will become positive.
【In summary，the $\mathrm{NaCl}$ side will become positive.】

A $0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaCl}$ solution was placed in contact with a $0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaNO}_{3}$ solution. Which side of the junction is positive?The side of the junction where the $0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaCl}$ solution is placed is positive.

When a solution with a higher concentration of a particular ion is placed in contact with a solution with a lower concentration of the same ion, an ion will migrate from the low-concentration solution to the high-concentration solution. In this case, the $0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaCl}$ solution has a lower concentration of the ion than the $0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaNO_{3}}$ solution, so the $0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaCl}$ solution will have a higher concentration of the ion. This means that the $0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaCl}$ solution will have a higher concentration of the ion than the $0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaNO_{3}}$ solution, and therefore the $0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaCl}$ solution will have a positive charge on one side of the junction.

A $0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaCl}$ solution was placed in contact with a $0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaNO}_{3}$ solution. Which side of the junction is positive?The side of the junction with the higher concentration of positively charged ions will be the positive side. In this case, the $0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaCl}$ solution has positively charged ions (Na+), while the $0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaNO_{3}}$ solution has negatively charged ions (NO3-). Therefore, the positive side of the junction will be the side of the solution with the higher concentration of positively charged ions, which is the side of the solution containing the $0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaCl}$ solution.

【answer】Calculate changes in electron potential based on known equations

Solution From Equation 14-10, we find the potential with negligible $\mathrm{OH}^{-}$at $\mathrm{pH} 5.5$ :
$E=\text { constant }-0.05916 \log \left[1.0 \times 10^{-4}\right]=\text { constant }+236.6 \mathrm{mV}$
At $\mathrm{pH} 10.50,\left[\mathrm{OH}^{-}\right]=3.2 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{M}$, so the electrode potential is
$\begin{aligned}
E & =\text { constant }-0.05916 \log \left[1.0 \times 10^{-4}+(0.1)\left(3.2 \times 10^{-4}\right)\right] \\
& =\text { constant }+229.5 \mathrm{mV}
\end{aligned}$
The change is $229.5-236.6=-7.1 \mathrm{mV}$, which is quite significant. If you didn't know about the $\mathrm{pH}$ change, you would think that the concentration of $\mathrm{F}^{-}$had increased by $32 \%$.
【In summary，The change is $229.5-236.6=-7.1 \mathrm{mV}$】

A fluoride ion-selective electrode has a selectivity coefficient $K_{\mathrm{F}}^{\mathrm{Pot}}{ }_{, \mathrm{OH}^{-}}=0.1$. What will be the change in electrode potential when $1.0 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{M} \mathrm{F}^{-}$at $\mathrm{pH} 5.5$ is raised to $\mathrm{pH} 10.5$ ?The change in electrode potential can be calculated using the Nernst equation:

$\mathrm{E_{g}} = \sum\_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathrm{K}_{i}^{\mathrm{Pot}}} \mathrm{[H}^{+}]_{i} - \sum\_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathrm{K}_{i}^{\mathrm{G}}} \mathrm{[H}^{+}]_{i}$

where $\mathrm{K}_{i}^{\mathrm{Pot}}$ is the potentiostatic factor at pH $i$, $\mathrm{K}_{i}^{\mathrm{G}}$ is the gradient factor at pH $i$, $\mathrm{[H}^{+}]_{i}$ is the current density at pH $i$ from an external source (in this case, the $1.0 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{M} \mathrm{F}^{-}$ at pH 5.5), and the sum is taken over all pH values.

Since the selectivity coefficient is defined as the ratio of the potential change at a given pH to the current density, we can rewrite the Nernst equation as:

$\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{F}}^{\mathrm{Pot}} = \frac{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{F}}^{\mathrm{G}}} \mathrm{[H}^{+}]}$

Substituting this expression into the Nernst equation, we get:

$\mathrm{E_{g}} = \sum\_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{F}}^{\mathrm{G}}} \mathrm{[H}^{+}]_{i} - \sum\_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{F}}^{\mathrm{G}}} \mathrm{[H}^{+}]_{i}$

$= \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{F}}^{\mathrm{G}}\sum\_{i=1}^{n} \mathrm{[H}^{+}]_{i}$

The change in the selectivity coefficient can be calculated by subtracting the selectivity coefficient at the beginning and end of the range from the selectivity coefficient at the midpoint:

$\mathrm{\Delta}K_{\mathrm{F}}^{\mathrm{Pot}} = \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{F}}^{\mathrm{Pot}}({pH}_{10.5}) - \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{F}}^{\mathrm{Pot}}({pH}_{5.5})$

Substituting the given values, we get:

$\mathrm{\Delta}K_{\mathrm{F}}^{\mathrm{Pot}} = 0.1 \times (10^{-14}/10^{-5.5) \approx 10^{-9}$

The change in the selectivity coefficient is approximately $10^{-9}$ V/m at pH 10.5.

What will be the change in electrode potential when $1.0 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{M} \mathrm{F}^{-}$at $\mathrm{pH} 5.5$ is raised to $\mathrm{pH} 10.5$ ?The change in electrode potential can be calculated using the Nernst equation:

What concentration of EDTA should be added to $0.010 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{CaY}^{2-}$ at $\mathrm{pH} 6.00$ to give $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}\right]=$ $1.0 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{M}$ ?【analysis】EDTA changes the concentration of various elements in the solution
【answer】Calculate using relevant equations

From Equation 14-17, we write$[\text { EDTA }]=\frac{\left[\mathrm{CaY}^{2-}\right]}{K_{\mathrm{f}} \alpha_{\mathrm{Y}^{4}-\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}\right]}}=\frac{0.010}{\left(10^{10.65}\right)\left(1.8 \times 10^{-5}\right)\left(1.00 \times 10^{-6}\right)}=0.012_{4} \mathrm{M}$
These are practical concentrations of $\mathrm{CaY}^{2-}$ and of EDTA.
【In summary，】EDTA=$0.012_{4} \mathrm{M}$

What concentration of EDTA should be added to $0.010 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{CaY}^{2-}$ at $\mathrm{pH} 6.00$ to give $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}\right]=$ $1.0 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{M}$ ?To determine the concentration of EDTA needed to give [Ca2+] = 1.0 x 10^-6 M at pH 6.00, you can use the following equation:

Ca2+ concentration = K x EDTA concentration

Where K is the dissociation constant for Ca2+ in itsEDTA complex.

First, you will need to determine the dissociation constant K. You can use the following formula to calculate K from the literature or from a database:

K = 4.8 x 10^-10

Next, you can use the EDTA concentration and the dissociation constant to calculate the EDTA concentration needed to give the desired [Ca2+] concentration:

EDTA concentration = K / [Ca2+]

EDTA concentration = 4.8 x 10^-10 / (1.0 x 10^-6) = 4.8 x 10^-4 M

So, to give [Ca2+] = 1.0 x 10^-6 M at pH 6.00, you should add a concentration of 4.8 x 10^-4 M EDTA to the solution.

What concentration of EDTA should be added to $0.010 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{CaY}^{2-}$ at $\mathrm{pH} 6.00$ to give $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}\right]=$ $1.0 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{M}$ ?To determine the concentration of EDTA needed to give $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}\right]=$ $1.0 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{M}$ in $0.010 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{CaY}^{2-}$ at $\mathrm{pH} 6.00$, you can use the following formula:

Ca2+ concentration = (EDTA concentration x Ka x pH) / (2 x l)

Where:

* Ka is the acid dissociation constant for $\mathrm{CaY}^{2-}$
* pH is the pH of the solution

First, we need to determine the acid dissociation constant Ka for $\mathrm{CaY}^{2-}$ at $\mathrm{pH} 6.00$. The Ka value can be calculated using the following formula:

Ka = ([H+] x Y- + 2 x [Ca2+]) / ([CaY2-]^2)

Substituting the given values, we get:

Ka = (1.0 x 10^-6 x 2 + 2 x 1.0 x 10^-6) / (0.010 x (1.0 x 10^-6)^2) = 4.0 x 10^-9

Next, we can use the formula for the Ca2+ concentration to calculate the EDTA concentration needed to give the desired $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}\right]=$ $1.0 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{M}$:

EDTA concentration = ($\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}\right]$ x Ka x pH) / (2 x l)

EDTA concentration = (1.0 x 10^-6 x 4.0 x 10^-9 x 6.0) / (2 x 10^-3) = 6.0 x 10^-5 M

Therefore, the concentration of EDTA needed to give $\left[\mathrm{Ca}^{2+}\right]=$ $1.0 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{M}$ in $0.010 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{CaY}^{2-}$ at $\mathrm{pH} 6.00$ is $6.0 x 10^-5 M.

$=$ constant $+0.05916 \log \left[\left(1.00 \times 10^{-3}\right)+\left(36 \times 10^{-8}\right)\right]$

For $5.00 \mathrm{mM} \mathrm{Na}^{+}$at $\mathrm{pH} 8.00$, we have
$E=+0.139+0.05916 \log \left[\left(5.00 \times 10^{-3}\right)+\left(36 \times 10^{-8}\right)\right]$

$=0.007 \mathrm{~V}$ 
【In summary，(a) $0.003 \mathrm{~V}$ (b) $0.007 \mathrm{~V}$】

One glass-membrane sodium ion-selective electrode has a selectivity coefficient $K_{\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{H}^{+}}^{\mathrm{Pot}}=36$. When this electrode was immersed in $1.00 \mathrm{mM} \mathrm{NaCl}$ at $\mathrm{pH} 8.00$, a potential of $-38 \mathrm{mV}$ (versus S.C.E.) was recorded.

(b) What would the potential be for $1.00 \mathrm{mM} \mathrm{NaCl}$ at $\mathrm{pH} 3.87$ ? You can see that $\mathrm{pH}$ is a critical variable for the sodium electrode.(a) The selectivity coefficient for the sodium ion is given by $K_{\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{H}^{+}}^{\mathrm{Pot}}=36$. This means that for every unit of current, 36 units of protons will be able to migrate through the glass membrane to the anode (i.e., the region with the higher potential) and 36 units of sodium ions will be able to migrate through the glass membrane to the cathode (i.e., the region with the lower potential).

If the electrode is immersed in $5.00 \mathrm{mM} \mathrm{NaCl}$ at $\mathrm{pH} 8.00$, the potential difference across the membrane is $36 \times 5 = 180\ \mathrm{mV}$. This means that the anode has a potential of $+36\ \mathrm{mV}$, while the cathode has a potential of $+36\ \mathrm{mV}$ due to the equal potential at both ends of the membrane.

If the electrode is immersed in $5.00 \mathrm{mM} \mathrm{NaCl}$ at $\mathrm{pH} 8.00$, the selectivity coefficient is $K_{\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{H}^{+}}^{\mathrm{Pot}}=36$ and the potential at the anode is $-38\ \mathrm{mV}$, so the potential at the cathode is $+38\ \mathrm{mV}$. This means that the anode has a potential of $-38\ \mathrm{mV}$, while the cathode has a potential of $+38\ \mathrm{mV}$ due to the selectivity of the electrode.

If the electrode is immersed in $5.00 \mathrm{mM} \mathrm{NaCl}$ at $\mathrm{pH} 3.87$, the selectivity coefficient is $K_{\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{H}^{+}}^{\mathrm{Pot}}=36$ and the potential at the anode is $-38\ \mathrm{mV}$, so the potential at the cathode is $+38\ \mathrm{mV}$ due to the selectivity of the electrode.

(b) The selectivity coefficient for the sodium ion at $\mathrm{pH} 3.87$ is given by $K_{\mathrm{Na}^{+}, \mathrm{H}^{+}}^{\mathrm{Pot}}=36$ and the potential at the anode is $-38\ \mathrm{mV}$, so the potential at the cathode is $+38\ \mathrm{mV}$ due to the selectivity of the electrode.

Standard potentials: indigo tetrasulfonate, $0.36 \mathrm{~V} ; \mathrm{Fe}[\mathrm{CN}]_{6}^{3-}$ | $\mathrm{Fe}[\mathrm{CN}]_{6}^{4-}, 0.356 \mathrm{~V} ; \mathrm{Tl}^{3+} \mid \mathrm{Tl}^{+}, 0.77 \mathrm{~V}$. The end-point potential will be between 0.356 and $0.77 \mathrm{~V}$. Indigo tetrasulfonate changes color near $0.36 \mathrm{~V}$. Therefore, it will not be a useful indicator for this titration.

Would indigo tetrasulfonate be a suitable redox indicator for the titration of $\mathrm{Fe}(\mathrm{CN})_{6}^{4-}$ with $\mathrm{Tl}^{3+}$ in $1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{HCl}$ ? (Hint: The potential at the equivalence point must be between the potentials

A solid mixture weighing $0.05485 \mathrm{~g}$ contained only ferrous ammonium sulfate and ferrous chloride. The sample was dissolved in $1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}$, and the $\mathrm{Fe}^{2+}$ required $13.39 \mathrm{~mL}$ of $0.01234 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{Ce}^{4+}$ for complete oxidation to $\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$. Calculate the weight percent of $\mathrm{Cl}$ in the original sample.
$\begin{array}{cc}
\mathrm{FeSO}_{4} \cdot\left(\mathrm{NH}_{4}\right)_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4} \cdot 6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} & \mathrm{FeCl}_{2} \cdot 6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \\
\text { Ferrous ammonium sulfate } & \text { Ferrous chloride } \\
\text { FM } 392.13 & \text { FM } 234.84\end{array}$【analysis】Solubility of ammonium ferrous sulfate
【answer】Calculate based on the mass of ferrous sulfate and ferrous chloride

Let $x=\mathrm{mg}$ of $\mathrm{FeSO}_{4} \cdot\left(\mathrm{NH}_{4}\right)_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4} \cdot 6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$ and $(54.85-x)=$ $\mathrm{mg}$ of $\mathrm{FeCl}_{2} \cdot 6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$.
$\mathrm{mmol}$ of $\left.\mathrm{Ce}^{4+}=\mathrm{mmol} \mathrm{FeSO}_{4} \cdot\left(\mathrm{NH}_{4}\right)_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4} \cdot 6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}+\mathrm{mmol} \mathrm{FeCl}\right)_{2} \cdot 6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$ $(13.39 \mathrm{~mL})(0.01234 \mathrm{M})=\frac{x \mathrm{mg}}{392.13 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{mmol}}+\frac{(54.85-x)}{234.84 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{mmol}}$
$\Rightarrow x=40.01 \mathrm{mg} \mathrm{FeSO}{ }_{4} \cdot\left(\mathrm{NH}_{4}\right)_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4} \cdot 6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$
Mass of $\mathrm{FeCl}_{2} \cdot 6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}=14.84 \mathrm{mg}=0.06319 \mathrm{mmol}=4.48 \mathrm{mg} \mathrm{Cl}$
$\mathrm{wt} \% \mathrm{Cl}=\frac{4.48 \mathrm{mg}}{54.85 \mathrm{mg}} \times 100=8.17 \%$
【In summary，$\mathrm{wt} \% \mathrm{Cl}=8.17 \%$】

A solid mixture weighing $0.05485 \mathrm{~g}$ contained only ferrous ammonium sulfate and ferrous chloride. The sample was dissolved in $1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}$, and the $\mathrm{Fe}^{2+}$ required $13.39 \mathrm{~mL}$ of $0.01234 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{Ce}^{4+}$ for complete oxidation to $\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$. Calculate the weight percent of $\mathrm{Cl}$ in the original sample.
$\begin{array}{cc}
\mathrm{FeSO}_{4} \cdot\left(\mathrm{NH}_{4}\right)_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4} \cdot 6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} & \mathrm{FeCl}_{2} \cdot 6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \\
\text { Ferrous ammonium sulfate } & \text { Ferrous chloride } \\
\text { FM } 392.13 & \text { FM } 234.84\end{array}$The weight percent of Cl in the original sample can be calculated as follows:

1. First, we need to determine the amount of each ion in the solution. Since only ferrous ammonium sulfate and ferrous chloride were present in the sample, we know that the solution contains only Fe2+ and Cl- ions.
2. The amount of Fe2+ can be determined by the reaction:

Fe2+ + Ce4+ + 2e- -> Fe3+ + Ce2+

where 2 moles of Ce4+ are required to convert 1 mole of Fe2+ to Fe3+.

The given amount of Ce4+ is 0.01234 M, so the amount of Fe2+ can be calculated as:

Fe2+ = (0.01234 M) / (2 \* 0.01234 M/mol) = 0.00618 mol
3. The amount of Cl- can be determined by the reaction:

Cl- + H+ -> HCl

where 1 mole of H+ is required to generate 1 mole of Cl-.

Since the solution is 1 M H2SO4, the amount of H+ is 1 M. The amount of Cl- can be calculated as:

Cl- = (1 M) / (1 M/mol) = 1 mol
4. The total mass of the solution can be calculated as:

M = (0.05485 g) / (0.00618 mol + 1 mol) = 0.8848 g
5. The weight percent of Cl in the solution can be calculated as:

w(Cl) = (1 mol / 0.8848 g) \* 100% = 10.98%

Therefore, the weight percent of Cl in the original sample is approximately 10.98%.

A solid mixture weighing $0.05485 \mathrm{~g}$ contained only ferrous ammonium sulfate and ferrous chloride. The sample was dissolved in $1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}$, and the $\mathrm{Fe}^{2+}$ required $13.39 \mathrm{~mL}$ of $0.01234 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{Ce}^{4+}$ for complete oxidation to $\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}$. Calculate the weight percent of $\mathrm{Cl}$ in the original sample.
$\begin{array}{cc}
\mathrm{FeSO}_{4} \cdot\left(\mathrm{NH}_{4}\right)_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4} \cdot 6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} & \mathrm{FeCl}_{2} \cdot 6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \\
\text { Ferrous ammonium sulfate } & \text { Ferrous chloride } \\
\text { FM } 392.13 & \text { FM } 234.84\end{array}$The first step to solve this problem is to determine the amount of each ion in the solution. Since the sample was only ferrous ammonium sulfate and ferrous chloride, we know that there is a fixed amount of both ions.

First, we can calculate the amount of ferrous ammonium sulfate (FeSO4·NH42SO4) based on the amount of ferrous ion and the formula for the摩尔质量 of FeSO4·NH42SO4.

The amount of ferrous ammonium sulfate (FeSO4·NH42SO4) = 0.05485 g / (55.85 g/mol + 14.01 g/mol + 4.01 g/mol) = 0.0005485 mol

Next, we can calculate the amount of ferrous chloride (FeCl2·6H2O) based on the amount of ferrous ion and the formula for the摩尔质量 of FeCl2·6H2O.

The amount of ferrous chloride (FeCl2·6H2O) = 0.05485 g / (55.85 g/mol + 2 \times 35.45 g/mol) = 0.000234 mol

Since the sample contained only ferrous ammonium sulfate and ferrous chloride, the total amount of ferrous ions in the solution is equal to the amount of ferrous ammonium sulfate.

The total amount of ferrous ions in the solution = 0.0005485 mol

Next, we can use the information that the ferrous ammonium sulfate requires 13.39 mL of 0.01234 M Ce4+ for complete oxidation to Fe3+ to calculate the amount of Ce4+ in the solution.

The amount of Ce4+ in the solution = 0.01234 M x 13.39 mL / 0.01234 M = 0.00016 mol

We can then use the fact that the Ce4+ and Fe2+ are in the ratio of 1:1 to calculate the amount of Fe2+ in the solution.

The amount of Fe2+ in the solution = 0.00016 mol / 1 = 0.00016 mol

Finally, we can calculate the amount of Cl- in the solution by subtracting the amounts of ferrous ammonium sulfate and ferrous chloride from the total amount of ferrous ions.

The amount of Cl- in the solution = 0.0005485 mol - 0.00016 mol = 0.0003885 mol

The weight percent of Cl- in the original sample can be calculated by dividing the amount of Cl- by the total mass of the original sample and multiplying by 100.

The weight percent of Cl- in the original sample = 0.0003885 mol / 0.05485 g x 100% = 7.08%

A $2.000-\mathrm{mL}$ volume containing $0.6113 \mathrm{mg}$ of cyclohexene $/ \mathrm{mL}$ is to be titrated in Figure 16-8. How much time is required for titration at a constant current of $4.825 \mathrm{~mA}$ ?【analysis】Calculate the titration time of the solution under constant current
【answer】step1:Calculate the number of moles of cyclohexene

The moles of cyclohexene are
$\frac{(2.000 \mathrm{~mL})(0.6113 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{mL})}{(82.146 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{mmol})}=0.01488 \mathrm{mmol}$
step2:Based on the above knowledge, use equation 16-3 to solve

In Reactions 16-10 and 16-11, each mole of cyclohexene requires $1 \mathrm{~mol}$ of $\mathrm{Br}_{2}$, which requires $2 \mathrm{~mol}$ of electrons. For $0.01488 \mathrm{mmol}$ of cyclohexene to react, $0.02976 \mathrm{mmol}$ of electrons must flow. From Equation 16-3,
$\begin{gathered}
\text { Moles of } \mathrm{e}^{-}=\frac{I \cdot t}{F} \Rightarrow t=\frac{\left(\text { moles of } \mathrm{e}^{-}\right) F}{I} \\
t=\frac{\left(0.02976 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~mol}\right)(96485 \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{mol})}{\left(4.825 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{s}\right)}=595.1 \mathrm{~s}
\end{gathered}$
【In summary，It will require just under $10 \mathrm{~min}$ to complete the reaction.】

t = (V\_max - V\_min) / I

where V\_max is the maximum volume of the solution that has been completely titrated and V\_min is the volume of the solution at the beginning of the titration.

Since the volume of the solution at the beginning of the titration is not given, we cannot calculate the time directly. However, we can calculate the time required for titration by assuming that the solution is titrated to its maximum reaction potential (i.e., the point at which the solution has reached maximum color or transparency).

Assuming that the solution reaches its maximum reaction potential at the end of the titration, the time required for titration can be calculated as follows:

t = (V\_max - 0) / I = (1000 \* mL - 0) / (4.825 \* 10^-3 A) = 22222.2222222223 \* s

Therefore, it will take approximately 22222.222222223 seconds for the titration to be complete at a constant current of $4.825 \mathrm{~mA}$.

A $2.000-\mathrm{mL}$ volume containing $0.6113 \mathrm{mg}$ of cyclohexene $/ \mathrm{mL}$ is to be titrated in Figure 16-8. How much time is required for titration at a constant current of $4.825 \mathrm{~mA}$ ?The time required for titration can be calculated using the following equation:

t = (V \* C) / (2 \* n)

where:

t = time (s)
V = volume (mL)
C = current (mA)
n = number of equivalents (mol)

Assuming that the titration is done at a constant current of $4.825 \mathrm{~mA}$, the volume of the titration solution can be calculated as:

Therefore, it will take approximately 11.48 minutes to complete the titration at a constant current of $4.825 \mathrm{~mA}$.

A dilute $\mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}$ solution is to be electrolyzed with a pair of smooth Pt electrodes at a current density of $100 \mathrm{~A} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$ and a current of $0.100 \mathrm{~A}$. The products are $\mathrm{H}_{2}(\mathrm{~g})$ and $\mathrm{O}_{2}(\mathrm{~g})$ at 1.00 bar. Calculate the required voltage if the cell resistance is $2.00 \Omega$ and there is no concentration polarization. What voltage would be required if the Pt electrodes were replaced by Au electrodes?The required voltage can be calculated using the Nernst equation. The Nernst equation relates the voltage difference across the electrodes to the current density and the concentrations of the electrolytes.

First, we need to calculate the concentrations of the electrolytes in the solution. Since the solution is a dilute $\mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}$ solution, we can assume that the solution has a concentration of $c(\mathrm{Na}^{+}) = 2 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{M}$ and $c(\mathrm{SO}_{4}^{2-}) = 1 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{M}$.

The current density is $100 \mathrm{~A} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$ and the current is $0.100 \mathrm{~A}$, so the cell resistance is $2.00 \Omega$.

Using the Nernst equation, we can calculate the required voltage:

$$E = E_{0} - (RT / nF) ln(Q) = 0.500 - (0.5 \times 8.31 \times 2.00 / 0.100) ln(0.100) = 0.500 - 19.12 = -18.62 \Omega\text{V} $$

This means that the voltage required to achieve the desired current density and current is $18.62 \Omega\text{V}$ above the standard potential.

Now, let's consider what would happen if the Pt electrodes were replaced by Au electrodes. The current density and current would remain the same, but the cell resistance would be reduced to $1.00 \Omega$ instead of $2.00 \Omega$. Using the Nernst equation, we can calculate the required voltage:

$$E = E_{0} - (RT / nF) ln(Q) = 0.500 - (0.5 \times 8.31 \times 1.00 / 0.100) ln(0.100) = 0.500 - 17.63 = -17.63 \Omega\text{V} $$

This means that the voltage required to achieve the same current density and current with the Pt electrodes replaced by Au electrodes is also $17.63 \Omega\text{V}$ above the standard potential.

A dilute $\mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}$ solution is to be electrolyzed with a pair of smooth Pt electrodes at a current density of $100 \mathrm{~A} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$ and a current of $0.100 \mathrm{~A}$. The products are $\mathrm{H}_{2}(\mathrm{~g})$ and $\mathrm{O}_{2}(\mathrm{~g})$ at 1.00 bar. Calculate the required voltage if the cell resistance is $2.00 \Omega$ and there is no concentration polarization. What voltage would be required if the Pt electrodes were replaced by Au electrodes?The required voltage can be calculated using the Nernst equation:

$$E_{r} = E_{0} - (RT/nF) ln(Q) + (RT/nF) ln(I)$$

where $E_r$ is the required voltage, $E_0$ is the voltage at the anode of the Pt electrode, $R$ is the cell resistance, $T$ is the temperature, $n$ is the number of electrons transferred in the reaction, and $F$ is the Faraday constant.

Since the solution is a dilute $\mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}$ solution, we can assume that the reaction is:

$$\rm{2H_{2}O \to O_{2} + 4H_{2}}$$

The current density is $100 \mathrm{~A} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$ and the current is $0.100 \mathrm{~A}$, so the reaction rate is:

$$\rm{Q = I \cdot I_{S} = 0.100 \times \frac{1}{2} = 0.050 \mathrm{~A}}$$

The cell resistance is $2.00 \Omega$ and the Faraday constant is $8.85 \times 10^{-12} \Omega \cdot C$. The temperature is not given, but it can be calculated from the reaction temperature, which is typically around $25^{\circ}C$ to $30^{\circ}C$ for air or $10^{\circ}C$ for water.

Using the formula for the Nernst equation, we can calculate the required voltage as follows:

$$E_{r} = E_{0} - (RT/nF) ln(Q) + (RT/nF) ln(I) = 0.600 \Omega - (8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times 258.15) ln(0.050) + (8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times 258.15) ln(0.100) = 0.600 \Omega - 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times ln(0.050) + 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times ln(0.100) = 0.600 \Omega - 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times ln(0.050) + 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times ln(0.1) = 0.600 \Omega - 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times ln(0.050) + 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times ln(1) = 0.600 \Omega - 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times ln(0.050) + 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times ln(1) = 0.600 \Omega$$

Therefore, the required voltage is $0.600 \Omega$.

If the Pt electrodes were replaced by Au electrodes, the required voltage would be the same as before because the reaction rate and the Faraday constant are the same for both metals.

(a) At what cathode potential will $\mathrm{Sb}(s)$ deposition commence from $0.010 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{SbO}^{+}$solution at $\mathrm{pH} 0.00$ ? Express this potential versus S.H.E. and versus $\mathrm{Ag} \mid \mathrm{AgCl}$.

(a) At what cathode potential will $\mathrm{Sb}(s)$ deposition commence from $0.010 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{SbO}^{+}$solution at $\mathrm{pH} 0.00$ ? Express this potential versus S.H.E. and versus $\mathrm{Ag} \mid \mathrm{AgCl}$.
$\mathrm{SbO}^{+}+2 \mathrm{H}^{+}+3 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Sb}(s)+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \quad E^{\circ}=0.208 \mathrm{~V}$
(b) What percentage of $0.10 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{Cu}^{2+}$ could be reduced electrolytically to $\mathrm{Cu}(s)$ before $0.010 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{SbO}^{+}$in the same solution begins to be reduced at $\mathrm{pH} 0.00$ ?(a) To find the cathode potential for $\mathrm{Sb}(s)$ deposition from an $0.010 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{SbO}^{+}$ solution at $\mathrm{pH} 0.00$, we can use the Nernst equation:

$$E_{\mathrm{cathode}} = E_{\mathrm{reduction}} - E_{\mathrm{氧化}} - 2E_{\mathrm{AgCl}}$$

where $E_{\mathrm{reduction}}$ is the reaction quotient for the reduction reaction:

$$\mathrm{SbO}^{+} + 2\mathrm{H}^{+} + 3\mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Sb}(s) + \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$$

We know that the reaction quotient is:

$$\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{reduction}} = \frac{\mathrm{Sb}(s) + \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}}{\mathrm{SbO}^{+} + 2\mathrm{H}^{+} + 3\mathrm{e}^{-}}$$

Substituting the values given, we get:

$$\mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{reduction}} = \frac{\mathrm{Sb}(s) + \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}}{\mathrm{SbO}^{+} + 2\mathrm{H}^{+} + 3\mathrm{e}^{-}} = \frac{0.010 + \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}}{\mathrm{SbO}^{+} + 2\mathrm{H}^{+} + 3\mathrm{e}^{-}} = \frac{0.010 + \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}}{0.010 + 2\times 10^{-14} + 3\times 10^{-7}} = 1.05\times 10^{-9}$$

Now, we can use the Nernst equation to calculate the cathode potential:

$$E_{\mathrm{cathode}} = E_{\mathrm{reduction}} - E_{\mathrm{氧化}} - 2E_{\mathrm{AgCl}} = 0.208 - 0.010 - 2\times 10^{-7} = 0.198\text{ V}$$

To find the electrochemical potential (S.H.E) of $\mathrm{Sb}(s)$ at this cathode potential, we can use the Nernst equation again:

$$E_{\mathrm{Sb}(s)} = E_{\mathrm{cathode}} - \frac{RT}{N_{A}} = 0.198 - \frac{8.314\times 298}{6.02\times 10^{23}} = 0.185\text{ V}$$

To find the potential for $\mathrm{AgCl}$ at this cathode potential, we can use the Nernst equation again:

$$E_{\mathrm{AgCl}} = E_{\mathrm{Sb}(s)} - 2E_{\mathrm{Ag}} = 0.185 - 2\times 10^{-7} = 0.183\text{ V}$$

(b) To find the percentage of $0.10 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{Cu}^{2+}$ that can be reduced to $\mathrm{Cu}(s)$ before $0.010 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{SbO}^{+}$ in the same solution begins to be reduced at $\mathrm{pH} 0.00$, we can first calculate the amount of $\mathrm{SbO}^{+}$ that will be reduced at $\mathrm{pH} 0.00$ using the reaction equation:

$$\mathrm{SbO}^{+} + 2\mathrm{H}^{+} + 3\mathrm{e}^{-} \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Sb}(s) + \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}$$

We know that $0.010 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{SbO}^{+}$ corresponds to $0.010\text{ mol/L}$ of $\mathrm{SbO}^{+}$, so the number of $\mathrm{SbO}^{+}$ ions that will be reduced at $\mathrm{pH} 0.00$ is:

$$n_{\mathrm{SbO}^{+}} = 0.010\text{ mol/L} \times \frac{1\text{ L}}{1\text{ L}} = 0.010\text{ mol}$$

The number of electrons that will be released from the $\mathrm{SbO}^{+}$ ions is:

$$n_{\mathrm{e}} = n_{\mathrm{SbO}^{+}} \times 3 = 0.010\text{ mol} \times 3 = 0.030\text{ mol}$$

The current that will be generated by the reduction reaction is:

$$I = n_{\mathrm{e}} \times \frac{E_{\mathrm{cathode}}}{N_{A}} = 0.030\text{ mol} \times \frac{0.198\text{ V}}{6.02\times 10^{23}} = 5.95\times 10^{-12}\text{ A}$$

The current that can be generated by the reduction reaction is:

$$I_{\mathrm{total}} = I_{\mathrm{SbO}^{+}} + I_{\mathrm{Cu^{2+}}} = 0.010\text{ A} + 2.998\times 10^{-12}\text{ A} = 2.998\times 10^{-12}\text{ A}$$

The percentage of $0.10 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{Cu}^{2+}$ that can be reduced to $\mathrm{Cu}(s)$ before $0.010 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{SbO}^{+}$ in the same solution begins to be reduced at $\mathrm{pH} 0.00$ is:

$$\% = \frac{I_{\mathrm{total}}}{I_{\mathrm{Cu^{2+}}} \times V_{\mathrm{SbO}^{+}}} \times 100\% = \frac{2.998\times 10^{-12}}{2.998\times 10^{-12} \times 0.010} \times 100\% = 99.9\%$$

Therefore, $99.9\%$ of $0.10 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{Cu}^{2+}$ can be reduced electrolyetically to $\mathrm{Cu}(s)$ before $0.010 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{SbO}^{+}$ in the same solution begins to be reduced at $\mathrm{pH} 0.00$.
